Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: How does doubling your speed from 20 mph to 40 mph affect your vehicle's braking distance?
questions.explanation: Increasing your vehicle's speed will increase your vehicle's striking power and braking distance. Doubling your vehicle's speed from 20 to 40 mph will quadruple its braking distance.

questions.question: ABS allows you to:
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to help prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. With ABS equipped on your vehicle, you should drive and brake in the same manner that you would without it.

questions.question: Foundation brakes are used:
questions.answerA: Only on the front wheels of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Only on the rear wheels of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: On each wheel of a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Foundation brakes are used on each wheel of a CMV. The most common type of foundation brake is the s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: When experiencing cold weather, be sure to check your vehicle's alcohol evaporator:
questions.explanation: An alcohol evaporator can help prevent ice from building up in an air brake system. In cold weather, the evaporator should be checked and refilled every day.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side.
questions.answerC: Only use the side mirrors on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: Backing a commercial motor vehicle is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind you. When backing, make frequent checks of the mirrors on both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the other driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn't see you.
questions.explanation: Whenever you pass another driver, bicyclist, or pedestrian, you should assume as a precaution that they do not see you.

questions.question: Driving with a cargo of hanging meat in a trailer:
questions.answerA: Is discouraged during the summer months.
questions.answerB: Can be problematic because animals are attracted to the smell of the meat.
questions.answerC: Is challenging because the load has a high center of gravity.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: To prevent becoming an aggressive driver you should:
questions.answerC: Give other drivers the benefit of the doubt.
questions.explanation: To avoid engaging in aggressive driving behavior, it is helpful to give other drivers the benefit of the doubt. Assume that they have valid reasons for what they are doing and don't take their actions personally.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can help drivers see a larger area.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: To ensure that you do not slow down traffic when driving a large truck, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to pass another vehicle while driving uphill.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If a heavy load prevents your vehicle from keeping up with the speed of other traffic, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: It stops the compressor from pumping air.
questions.answerB: It turns on the air compressor.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the storage tanks. It stops pumping if the pressure in the tanks becomes too high, and begins pumping if the pressure becomes too low.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse, using driver's side backing:
questions.answerC: Is only recommended if it is raining.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: If other vehicles are having a difficult time getting around your truck on a road with two or more lanes, you should:
questions.explanation: You should stay in the right lane of a multilane road if your vehicle is being slowed down by a heavy load. Allow other vehicles to pass your truck using the left lane.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to cover cargo?
questions.answerA: To protect people from spilled cargo
questions.answerB: To protect the cargo from weather
questions.answerC: To protect the cargo from animals
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: When approaching a vehicle for a pre-trip inspection, a driver should look under the vehicle:
questions.answerA: To see if the vehicle is on an incline.
questions.answerB: To see if there are any fresh fluids on the ground.
questions.answerC: To see if the vehicle is in a parking spot.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle before an inspection, make note of its general condition and ensure that it is not damaged or leaning. Look under the vehicle for fresh leaks of oil, grease, or fuel. Check around the vehicle for hazards to movement, such as people, other vehicles, or low-hanging wires or tree limbs.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: A driver who stops at a green light could be:
questions.answerB: A driver who is color blind.
questions.answerC: A person who does not know the rules of the road.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they stop in inappropriate places, such as at green traffic lights.

questions.question: What is often found in compressed air?
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Mirrors should be:
questions.answerC: Checked only if there is a reason to suspect a problem.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should regularly check your mirrors, both to be aware of traffic and to check for problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be applied.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should be applied.
questions.answerC: Brakes should not be applied if the vehicle is left out of gear.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should be used whenever you park. If necessary, chock your wheels.

questions.question: On slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerB: Adjust your driving to match weather conditions.
questions.explanation: On a slippery road, you must adjust your driving speed to fit conditions. Because it will take longer for your vehicle to stop on a slippery road than on a dry road, you should increase your following distance when conditions are slippery. Avoid driving in a way that requires you to change speeds frequently.

questions.question: When in heavy traffic, the safest driving speed is:
questions.answerA: Slower than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerB: The same speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: Faster than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: In heavy traffic, it is safest to travel at the same speed as other vehicles. If two vehicles continue to drive in the same direction at the same speed, they cannot hit each other.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Is not available for vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is not helpful in most driving situations.
questions.answerC: Can help you maintain control when braking.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are compatible with air brakes and help a driver maintain control of their vehicle by preventing wheel lockup.

questions.question: When encountering a railroad crossing during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is moving too slowly.
questions.answerB: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: If you’re not sure what to do to extinguish a fire in your vehicle, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire in your vehicle, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: Parked delivery trucks may be hazardous because:
questions.answerB: People are often in a hurry when exiting such trucks and may not look for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Packages often fall out of the trucks and into the road.
questions.explanation: Passing parked delivery or postal trucks can be dangerous because the driver may be in a hurry and pull into traffic without warning, or may they suddenly step out of the vehicle without checking for other traffic.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerA: Usually have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: Usually have high centers of gravity.
questions.answerC: Are usually not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care to be driven, both because they have high centers of gravity and because the weight of the load can shift in transit.

questions.question: Once they have begun to drive after a tire on their vehicle has been changed, a driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the tire is wearing evenly.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the air pressure of the tire is still acceptable.
questions.explanation: Once you have begun to drive after a tire has been changed, you should stop after a short distance to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: When traveling at speeds under 40 mph, you should maintain at least ____ of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle's length.
questions.explanation: When traveling at speeds under 40 mph, you should allow a minimum of one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle's length. At faster speeds, add at least one additional second.

questions.question: When taking the driving test and asked to make a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use a turn signal since you were told to make the turn.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only to your right.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have ____ malfunction lamps to indicate when the ABS is not working.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with ABS have yellow malfunction lamps to alert drivers when the braking systems are not working. Be sure you know where the malfunction lamp on your vehicle is before beginning a trip.

questions.question: The heavier the vehicle:
questions.answerA: The less important the brakes become.
questions.answerB: The harder the brakes need to work.
questions.answerC: The quieter the brakes will sound.
questions.explanation: The heavier a vehicle is, the more the brakes will need to work to bring the vehicle to a complete stop.

questions.question: A bridge formula:
questions.answerA: Permits less weight per axle for axles that are close together.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern for drivers.
questions.explanation: Maximum axle weights are often set by a bridge formula, which sets a lower maximum weight for axles that are close together.

questions.question: Drowsy driving is most common during:
questions.explanation: Drowsy driving is most common during the night because people are naturally prone to be less alert in the hours during which they are normally asleep. If you must drive at night, take every precaution to prevent fatigued driving.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good rule when using turn signals?
questions.answerA: Signal early. Signal well before a turn or lane change.
questions.answerB: Signal continuously. Do not cancel a signal until the turn is completed.
questions.answerC: Don’t over-signal. If no one is near you, there is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: When using your turn signals, you should signal well before the turn or lane change, signal continuously throughout the turn or lane change, and cancel the signal after you have completed your move.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Hop directly from their seat to the ground.
questions.answerB: Maintain at least one point of contact with their vehicle.
questions.answerC: Be turned to face their vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: If a worker is present in a work zone, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: Slow to a speed under the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: When driving through a work zone, follow the posted speed limits. If workers are present, you should slow to a speed that is even lower than the posted limit.

questions.question: When driving in winter, which of the following should receive extra attention in a pre-trip inspection?
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection during the winter, you should pay extra attention to the coolant level and amount of antifreeze; the defrosting and heating equipment; the wiper blades and windshield washer; the tires and tire chains; the lights and reflectors; the windows and mirrors; the hand holds, steps, and deck plates; the radiator shuttles and winterfront; and exhaust system.

questions.question: Items on a flatbed:
questions.answerA: Are usually heavy enough to not need to be strapped down.
questions.answerB: Should not be strapped down if you are driving more slowly than 35 mph.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down to prevent it from shifting or falling off in transit.

questions.question: In hot weather, spots on the pavement where tar is bleeding:
questions.answerB: Offer the same amount of traction as the rest of the roadway.
questions.answerC: Offer more traction than the rest of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Tar in road pavement often rises to the surface of the road, or "bleeds," in very hot weather. Watch for such areas because they can be very slippery.

questions.question: A safety belt:
questions.answerA: Helps secure a driver in a crash.
questions.answerB: Allows a driver to be thrown within their vehicle in a crash.
questions.answerC: Makes it difficult for a driver to operate a vehicle.
questions.explanation: In the event of a crash, a safety belt keeps the driver of a commercial motor vehicle securely positioned behind the steering wheel. This both protects the driver from injury and makes it easier for them to maintain control of the vehicle.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you will need to check the engine oil level.

questions.question: When completing a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.answerB: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: Some air brake systems introduce alcohol into the system to:
questions.answerA: Make the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevent ice from forming in the brake system.
questions.answerC: Prevent people from breathing the air from the system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. An evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help inhibit the formation of ice in cold weather.

questions.question: A cracked rim should be:
questions.answerB: Relocated to one of a pair of dual tires.
questions.explanation: A driver should inspect wheels before a drive, specifically looking for damage on the wheels and rims. Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use.

questions.question: To affect a vehicle, ABS:
questions.answerB: Must be on the rear axle.
questions.answerC: Can be on as few as one axle.
questions.explanation: Anti-lock brakes on only a single axle still provides a driver with more control while braking than they would have without any anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, you can tell that your vehicle's ABS is not working if:
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the right side of the trailer flashes three times.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights flash and then turn off.
questions.explanation: When turning on your vehicle's engine, the lights on the dash should come on and then turn off. If the ABS malfunction light stays on, the system is not working properly. In the case of a truck with a trailer, if the yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on once the engine has been started, the system is not working properly.

questions.question: When driving on a long downhill slope, you should brake by:
questions.answerB: Mostly using the brakes and occasionally downshifting.
questions.answerC: Downshifting and then using the brakes.
questions.explanation: When approaching a long downgrade, you should shift into a lower gear then use proper braking techniques. Using the brakes alone could cause them to overheat and fail. The braking power of the engine, which is maximized by being in a lower gear, will be the principal way of controlling your speed on a downgrade.

questions.question: Water that has collected on a roadway can cause:
questions.explanation: The risk of hydroplaning begins when water has collected on the surface of a road.

questions.question: Drowsy driving is most common during:
questions.explanation: Drowsy driving is most common during the night because people are naturally prone to be less alert in the hours during which they are normally asleep. If you must drive at night, take every precaution to prevent fatigued driving.

questions.question: When making a tight maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your mirrors, as they can be distracting.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors, but not too frequently.
questions.explanation: It is important for you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. To do this, regularly check your mirrors. You should make a particular point of checking your mirrors when merging, changing lanes, turning, and performing tight maneuvers.

questions.question: How long should it take for oil pressure to reach a normal level when starting a vehicle?
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the oil pressure should come up to a normal level within seconds. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: The more alcohol in the body:
questions.answerA: The quicker the liver will digest the alcohol.
questions.answerB: The less effect the alcohol will have on the individual.
questions.answerC: The longer it will take to remove the alcohol from the body.
questions.explanation: The body removes alcohol at a fixed rate. The more alcohol consumed, the longer it will take for the body to remove the alcohol from its system.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see other vehicles, such as at dawn or dusk, you should:
questions.explanation: When driving at dawn, at dusk, or in inclement weather, you should use your headlights on their low beam setting to increase your visibility.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant will be asked to:
questions.explanation: The vehicle inspection test will include a check of the oil level. You must show that it is within a safe operating range.

questions.question: If using spring brakes when hauling a heavy load, a complete stop will:
questions.answerC: Take a short amount of time.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes do not work on all axles. If your vehicle's spring brakes activate due to low pressure in an air brake system, your vehicle will need a longer distance to stop than usual, especially if you are carrying a heavy load.

questions.question: The tire load for a tire is stated:
questions.answerA: On the side of the tire.
questions.answerB: On the inside of the tire.
questions.answerC: On the inside of the driver’s door.
questions.explanation: The tire load, or the maximum safe weight that a tire can carry at a given pressure, is stated on the side of each tire.

questions.question: Looking far ahead of your vehicle while driving is:
questions.answerA: Discouraged, as there is little you can do about something far up the road.
questions.answerB: Encouraged to help you identify hazards as early as possible.
questions.explanation: Good drivers look down the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. This makes it possible to identify hazards early, when drivers are more likely to have time to respond appropriately.

questions.question: When using a mirror, you should:
questions.answerB: Stare at the mirror for a long time.
questions.answerC: Use only the driver’s side mirror.
questions.explanation: When making mirror checks, you should look at the mirrors fairly quickly. If you spend too much time looking in a mirror, you may travel a substantial distance down the road without seeing what is coming up ahead.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation in your personal car:
questions.answerB: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Law enforcement will tell your employer.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: The effects of alcohol are felt:
questions.answerB: Only after several drinks have been consumed.
questions.explanation: Alcohol impairment can begin with the first drink consumed. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while impaired by alcohol.

questions.question: An alcohol evaporator in an air brake system:
questions.answerA: Makes the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevents ice from forming in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Lubricates parts of the braking system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems include an evaporator that introduces alcohol into the system. The alcohol can help prevent ice from forming within the system.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that the nuts are loose. If you find rust near the wheel nuts, check their tightness before beginning to drive.

questions.question: Antifreeze helps to keep an engine functioning properly:
questions.answerA: But only if it is cold outside.
questions.answerC: Both when it is cold and hot outside.
questions.explanation: It is always important to have enough water and antifreeze in a vehicle's cooling system. Despite the name, antifreeze is beneficial to an engine even in hot weather.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerA: Are not safe to be used.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable only when traveling at speeds under 40 mph.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are never safe for use.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure there is a gap between the kingpin and the locking jaws.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a tractor/trailer coupling, look into the fifth wheel gap and make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.

questions.question: While driving, ____ generally holds spring brakes in place.
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: If a vehicle begins to hydroplane, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Release the accelerator and push in the clutch.
questions.answerC: Pull in the clutch and brake.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, you can regain control by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: When checking your windshield wiper blades, the blades should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check the wiper blades for damage, stiff rubber, and proper securement.

questions.question: A driver should:
questions.answerA: Always use turn signals when changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Only use turn signals if there is a vehicle next to them.
questions.answerC: Not use a turn signal if a lane change is obvious.
questions.explanation: Always signal before turning or changing lanes to ensure that other drivers are aware of your intentions.

questions.question: Do not base your decision to shift gears on:
questions.answerC: The actions of the vehicle next to you.
questions.explanation: One way to know when it is time to shift gears is to learn your vehicle's operating rpm range. You should shift up when your engine reaches the top of that range. You can also learn which speeds each gear is good for and shift up based on your speedometer.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerA: Pressed down quickly with both feet.
questions.explanation: When braking, push the pedal down gradually to ensure that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: Shortly after a tire has been changed, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop to make sure the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop a short while later to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: When driving on a long downhill slope, you should brake by:
questions.answerB: Mostly using the brakes and occasionally downshifting.
questions.answerC: Downshifting and then using the brakes.
questions.explanation: When approaching a long downgrade, you should shift into a lower gear then use proper braking techniques. Using the brakes alone could cause them to overheat and fail. The braking power of the engine, which is maximized by being in a lower gear, will be the principal way of controlling your speed on a downgrade.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: What should happen before the air pressure in an air brake system tank falls below 55 psi?
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be unable to shift out of gear.
questions.explanation: The low air pressure warning signal must activate before the air supply pressure drops below 55 psi in the air tank. If the warning signal does not turn on when being tested during an inspection, the vehicle is not safe to drive.

questions.question: As the driver of a truck carrying a load, you are responsible for all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Knowing the phone numbers of all fire departments along your intended route of travel.
questions.explanation: It is the driver's responsibility to inspect their cargo; recognize overloading or poorly balanced weight; know that the cargo is properly secured and does not obscure the driver's view; and know that the cargo does not restrict access to emergency equipment. The driver is responsible for their cargo even if they were not the one who initially loaded and secured the cargo.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Explain what you would inspect and why.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. During this inspection, you must explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why you are inspecting those items.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.answerA: It is safe to drive on a tire that is missing one or two lug nuts.
questions.answerB: A cracked lock ring on a rim is safe if you are not driving faster than 55 mph.
questions.answerC: A missing clamp on a rim is dangerous and should be corrected.
questions.explanation: Missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs are dangerous, as are mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings. Be sure your tires and rims are in good condition before operating your commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: Driving at night is usually:
questions.answerA: More difficult than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Simpler than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: There are several reasons why driving at night is more difficult than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued drivers on the road.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Tread of 3/32 of an inch in the grooves of the front tires
questions.explanation: When checking the tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, make sure the tires have sufficient tread. There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread in every major groove of the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on the other tires. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: When parked on a flat surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use wheel chocks to prevent your vehicle from moving.
questions.answerC: Use wheel chocks, but only if you have applied the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When parking on a level surface, you should use wheel chocks. If the vehicle is not equipped with spring brakes, this is essential to prevent the trailer from moving.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the tire has remained clean.
questions.explanation: After changing a tire, you should stop a short distance later to recheck the tightness of the tire's lug nuts.

questions.question: If a driver has stopped on the road and is placing triangles to warn other motorists:
questions.answerA: The triangles should be held between the driver and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: The triangles should be carried behind the driver's back to prevent them from being seen by other drivers until they are placed.
questions.answerC: The triangles should be held as low as possible.
questions.explanation: For your own safety, when placing reflective warning triangles, you should carry them between your body and the oncoming traffic.

questions.question: When slowing down, you should ____ to warn other drivers
questions.explanation: Before slowing down, it can be a good idea to lightly tap your brakes. This will cause your brake lights to flash, providing a warning to motorists behind you.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Is not available for most trucks.
questions.answerB: Is not helpful in most situations.
questions.explanation: Beginning between 1997 and 1999, most commercial vehicles, trailers, and dollies are required to be equipped with ABS.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: It is best not to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive under foggy conditions, be sure to decrease your speed.

questions.question: When driving, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Avoid using your mirrors while in heavy traffic.
questions.answerB: Look only to the front and right side of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Look to the front, sides, and rear of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Scan the road ahead and make regular checks of the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while you are driving.

questions.question: If there is a cargo fire in a box trailer:
questions.answerA: The trailer doors should be opened.
questions.answerB: The trailer doors should not be opened.
questions.answerC: A large, heavy blanket should be put over the trailer.
questions.explanation: The doors of a trailer should be not be opened in the event of a cargo fire, especially if the cargo includes hazardous materials. Opening trailer doors would increase the fire's oxygen supply, potentially causing the fire to increase in size.

questions.question: An alcohol evaporator is especially important:
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. This evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help prevent ice from forming in cold weather.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, if one air system is very low on pressure:
questions.answerA: None of the brakes will work at all.
questions.answerB: Either the front or rear brakes will not be fully operable.
questions.answerC: There is usually no noticeable effect.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, either the front or rear brakes will not be fully operable if one of the air systems gets too low on pressure. If the air pressure in either tank gets too low while you are driving, you should exit the road and park as soon as possible.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should stay on for several minutes.
questions.answerB: Should turn off within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Should stay on until manually turned off.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery when it first begins to rain because:
questions.answerB: The fresh rain mixes with oil on the roadway.
questions.answerC: The water has nowhere to go.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check all belts for tightness and excessive wear. You should learn how much "give" is appropriate for each belt.

questions.question: If one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing when a vehicle is inspected:
questions.answerA: The vehicle’s driver will be allowed to drive, but only at reduced speeds.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be put out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will be fine to drive since most of the spring is in place.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's suspension, you should look for broken or missing leaves in the leaf springs. Any defect of this kind is dangerous. If one-fourth or more of the leaves are missing from any leaf spring, the vehicle must be put out-of-service.

questions.question: If a vehicle is power steering-equipped, the hoses should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the locking jaws are open.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer coupling, you should make sure the fifth wheel locking jaws are closed around the shank of the kingpin, not the head of the kingpin.

questions.question: Why are multi-speed axles and auxiliary transmissions used?
questions.answerA: To make a vehicle operate more smoothly
questions.answerC: To improve a vehicle's gas mileage
questions.explanation: On many vehicles, multi-speed rear axles and auxiliary transmissions are used to provide extra gears.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired and yawning a lot while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel tired while driving, you should stop to get some sleep. Trying to push on to reach your destination while tired is dangerous. You should not rely on caffeine to keep you awake.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors before a trip:
questions.answerA: No part of your vehicle should be visible in any mirror.
questions.answerB: Part of your vehicle should be visible in the mirrors.
questions.answerC: More than half of each mirror should show the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When properly adjusted, your mirrors should each display some part of your vehicle. Being able to see your own vehicle in your mirrors will give you a point of reference when judging the positions of other objects.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tank drains are used to remove water and compressor oil from the air tanks. When operating a drain, be sure to drain the tank completely.

questions.question: Items on a flatbed:
questions.answerA: Are usually heavy enough to not need to be strapped down.
questions.answerB: Should not be strapped down if you are driving more slowly than 35 mph.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down to prevent it from shifting or falling off in transit.

questions.question: A tread depth of ____ should be in every major groove of a front tire.
questions.explanation: For safe operation, a commercial motor vehicle needs a tread depth of 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and a tread depth of 2/32 of an inch on other tires.

questions.question: How soon after starting a trip must cargo securement be checked?
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled thereafter. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: The two markings on a front brake limiting valve usually read:
questions.explanation: Some vehicles with air brake systems manufactured before 1975 have a front brake limiting valve with "normal" and "slippery" settings.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect stopping distance include the vehicle's speed, its weight, and the traction provided by the road surface.

questions.question: While driving, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Not be concerned with what is happening on the sides of their vehicle.
questions.answerB: Be concerned with what is happening on all sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with what is happening behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Scan the road ahead and make regular checks of the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while you are driving.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, you can tell that your vehicle's ABS is not working if:
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the right side of the trailer flashes three times.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights flash and then turn off.
questions.explanation: When turning on your vehicle's engine, the lights on the dash should come on and then turn off. If the ABS malfunction light stays on, the system is not working properly. In the case of a truck with a trailer, if the yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on once the engine has been started, the system is not working properly.

questions.question: When inspecting your tires, you do not want to find:
questions.answerA: Tire tread that is 4/32 of an inch deep.
questions.explanation: There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on front tires and 2/32 of an inch on other tires. Valve stems should not be cut or cracked. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: When checking your tires as part of the pre-trip inspection, you should look at the:
questions.explanation: When checking your tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, it is important to verify that the tire pressure is neither too low nor too high.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: Cargo with a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Can make a vehicle likely to tip over.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: If your brakes fail while you are traveling downhill and there is no available escape ramp, you should:
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail while you are driving downhill, you should first look for an escape ramp to stop your vehicle. If no ramp is available, you should look for an alternative place to bring your vehicle to a stop, such as an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, what is the maximum leakage rate that is safe for a single vehicle with air brakes?
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: When traveling long distances, you should:
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should take a break after every 100 miles or two hours of driving. Driving through the night, or during any other time when you would normally be asleep, raises the danger of fatigue.

questions.question: You should check and adjust your mirrors:
questions.explanation: Be sure to check your mirrors before beginning a drive. Your posture may change day to day and your mirrors may need to be adjusted.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections:
questions.answerA: Should never be done the same way two times in a row.
questions.answerB: Should always be done in the same order.
questions.answerC: Do not need to be done if the driver is familiar with the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection should be completed in the same order every time. This will make it easier for you to learn all of the steps and will make it less likely that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: If an unusual noise or feeling occurs in a vehicle while it is being driven, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle does alright until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check the situation to determine the proper solution.
questions.explanation: If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything while driving that does not feel right, you should have it checked out.

questions.question: If using a helper when backing a vehicle, the helper should be located:
questions.answerA: In front of the passenger's side of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: In front of the driver's side of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Near the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: When backing up, it is always a good idea for a driver to use a helper who can watch the vehicle's blind spots. The helper should stand near the back of the vehicle in a location where they are visible to the driver.

questions.question: Distracted driving can be avoided by:
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report from the previous driver:
questions.answerA: The driver should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely on the report.
questions.answerB: The driver should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerC: The driver should review the report.
questions.answerD: The driver should speak with the previous driver.
questions.explanation: As the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review any inspection report left by the previous driver.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard:
questions.answerA: You should always steer to the left.
questions.answerB: You may be able to drive onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: You should steer sharply in one direction.
questions.explanation: In some emergencies, the best strategy for avoiding a hazard may be to drive onto the shoulder. Most shoulders are strong enough to support the weight of a large vehicle.

questions.question: Water that has collected on a roadway can cause:
questions.explanation: The risk of hydroplaning begins when water has collected on the surface of a road.

questions.question: If a worker is present in a work zone, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: Slow to a speed under the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: When driving through a work zone, follow the posted speed limits. If workers are present, you should slow to a speed that is even lower than the posted limit.

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you will receive points if you:
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: A poor balance of weight in a trailer:
questions.explanation: Poorly balanced weight in a trailer can make handling unsafe. For example, either too little or too much weight on the front axle can make a vehicle difficult to steer. Weight should be distributed evenly from front to back and from side to side. It should be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Hop directly from their seat to the ground.
questions.answerB: Maintain at least one point of contact with their vehicle.
questions.answerC: Be turned to face their vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: A cargo van is:
questions.answerA: Usually the same height with or without a load.
questions.answerB: Usually taller with a heavy load than with a light load.
questions.answerC: Usually shorter with a heavy load than with a light load.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: If there is ice on the front of your side mirror:
questions.answerB: You can expect ice to be on the roadway.
questions.answerC: There will not be ice on the roadway.
questions.explanation: If your mirrors or wiper blades become icy while you are driving, you can expect the road surface to be icy as well.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with one or more trailers, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the trailers are straight. Mirror adjustment should be checked before the start of every trip.

questions.question: If you must back up, it is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Drive as fast as possible to complete the maneuver quickly.
questions.answerB: First walk the line of travel to look for obstacles.
questions.answerC: Use only the passenger side mirror.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, you should exit the cab and check your path for obstacles before beginning the maneuver. Drive as slowly as you can, checking your mirrors on both sides.

questions.question: The only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to:
questions.explanation: Most alcohol is removed from the body by the liver, which processes alcohol at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, techniques like drinking black coffee or taking a cold shower will not accelerate this process. The only thing you can do to become sober after drinking is allow your body the time it needs to eliminate the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: If a speed limit is posted, the posted speed:
questions.answerB: May be exceeded if passing another vehicle.
questions.answerC: May be exceeded if driving in a rural area.
questions.explanation: A maximum posted speed limit is the fastest a vehicle may travel under ideal circumstances. A driver should decrease their driving speed as conditions require. A driver should never exceed the legal speed limit.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerA: Not be used by the driver.
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Hydroplaning happens most often when:
questions.answerA: A vehicle is traveling faster than 60 mph.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is most likely to occur when driving on wet roads with tire pressure that is too low and tire tread that is too worn. If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should not light up or sound.
questions.answerB: Should turn on and shut off quickly.
questions.answerC: Should turn on and remain on.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the warning lights and buzzers should turn on, then quickly turn off.

questions.question: If you’re unfamiliar with the area in which you must back up, you should:
questions.answerA: Get out of your vehicle and walk around the area to become more familiar with it.
questions.answerB: Not use both side mirrors because it can be distracting.
questions.answerC: Wait for someone else to back up in the area so you can see how they do it.
questions.explanation: Before backing up, you should get out of your vehicle and look at your line of travel. Check your clearance to the sides and overhead.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Consists of two separate air brake systems that share a single set of controls.
questions.answerB: Is a single air brake system with two different sets of controls.
questions.answerC: Consists of one air brake system for the left side of the truck and one system for the right side of the truck, each with its own set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. The systems share a single set of brake controls, but each has its own air tanks, hoses, and lines. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles while the other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by one-half or more when traveling on packed snow.

questions.question: Improperly loaded cargo can:
questions.answerB: Hurt or kill the driver during a quick stop.
questions.answerC: Make it easier to stop a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Improperly secured or loaded cargo can be very dangerous. For example, loose cargo could fall in the event of a sudden stop, potentially injuring or even killing the driver.

questions.question: With the exception of the straight line backing exercise, a driver may exit their vehicle and check its position during testing exercises up to:
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic vehicle control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: If you have more than one license:
questions.answerC: You may get caught through the states' shared computer network.
questions.explanation: All states share driver information through a computerized database in order to prevent the issuance of multiple licenses to a single person. It is prohibited for a person to have more than one driver license.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerB: The air pressure has become too high.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: A cracked rim should be:
questions.answerB: Relocated to one of a pair of dual tires.
questions.explanation: A driver should inspect wheels before a drive, specifically looking for damage on the wheels and rims. Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use.

questions.question: Within 10 minutes of stopping on the side of the road, you must:
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you must place the appropriate emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: When parking, you should not use the parking brake if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: If your brakes are hot after coming down a steep grade, you should not use your parking brake when parking. Let your brakes cool before applying the parking brake or risk damaging the brakes.

questions.question: If there is ice on the front of your side mirror:
questions.answerB: You can expect ice to be on the roadway.
questions.answerC: There will not be ice on the roadway.
questions.explanation: If your mirrors or wiper blades become icy while you are driving, you can expect the road surface to be icy as well.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, but have the brakes repaired within a week.
questions.answerB: Pull over and inspect the brakes.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should immediately bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes. Inspect and repair the brakes as soon as possible.

questions.question: If you have an engine fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Open the hood as soon as possible.
questions.answerB: Turn off the engine as soon as possible.
questions.explanation: To keep an engine fire from spreading, you should turn off the vehicle's engine as soon as possible. Do not open the hood if you don't have to.

questions.question: What color malfunction lamps do vehicles equipped with ABS have?
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunction lamps are usually yellow. Even if the ABS isn't working properly, a driver will still have access to the vehicle's usual braking functions.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated while driving a large vehicle, do all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you find yourself being tailgated by another driver, you should increase your following distance and avoid making quick moves. Increasing your speed may only result in the other driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed. Do not turn on your taillights or flash your brake lights at the other driver.

questions.question: If a driver has stopped on the road and is placing triangles to warn other motorists:
questions.answerA: The triangles should be held between the driver and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: The triangles should be carried behind the driver's back to prevent them from being seen by other drivers until they are placed.
questions.answerC: The triangles should be held as low as possible.
questions.explanation: For your own safety, when placing reflective warning triangles, you should carry them between your body and the oncoming traffic.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load on a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: It is best not to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive under foggy conditions, be sure to decrease your speed.

questions.question: A person driving with an open window in cold weather may be:
questions.answerB: A person who is dressed inappropriately.
questions.answerC: A person who likes fresh air.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they have their windows rolled down in cold weather.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn the steering wheel as hard as possible.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch. This will help you to regain traction.

questions.question: The steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held with one hand to keep the other hand free.
questions.answerC: Held with one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands, placed on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: Skids happen when:
questions.answerA: Tires lose their grip on the road.
questions.answerB: There is too much weight in the trailer.
questions.explanation: Skids happen when tires' traction with the road surface decreases. This can be caused by over-braking, over-accelerating, over-steering, and driving too fast.

questions.question: Before attempting to put out an engine fire:
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The accelerator should be depressed to use up the remaining fuel.
questions.explanation: If you experience an engine fire, you should turn off the engine as soon as safely possible. Avoid opening the vehicle's hood when extinguishing the fire.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driver’s side is encouraged because:
questions.answerA: The driver will have the best possible view.
questions.answerB: Power lines should be on the passenger's side.
questions.answerC: Other drivers can offer assistance on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: When driving in reverse, it is always recommended that a driver backs their vehicle toward its left side. This will allow the driver the best possible view of the rear of their vehicle.

questions.question: Blocking a load:
questions.answerA: Is dangerous and should never be done.
questions.answerB: Is essential to preventing cargo from moving in transit.
questions.answerC: Is only done with liquid loads.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be blocked to prevent it from sliding around in transit. The shifting of weight in transit can make steering and handling difficult for the driver.

questions.question: What is Gross Combination Weight?
questions.answerA: The total weight of the powered unit, trailer, and cargo
questions.answerB: The total weight of a single vehicle without its load
questions.answerC: The maximum weight allowed by the manufacturer
questions.explanation: Gross Combination Weight (GCW) is the total weight of a powered unit, its trailer(s), and the cargo being carried.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: You should not use your mirrors:
questions.answerC: To determine how fast you are traveling.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be a part of your driving routine, it is particularly important to check your mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, and making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: Drivers talking to passengers in their vehicle should be viewed as:
questions.explanation: Drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers may be distracted from the task of driving. Use extra caution when driving near distracted drivers.

questions.question: If mirrors are dirty before starting a trip:
questions.answerA: They will likely become clean after driving a short distance.
questions.answerB: It should not be a concern.
questions.answerC: They should be cleaned before the vehicle is driven.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, be sure to check the mirrors and windshield for dirt and anything else that could interfere with your ability to see. Clean them as necessary.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, a separate air tank can be used:
questions.answerA: To make the air brakes work more effectively.
questions.answerB: To temporarily release the spring brakes.
questions.answerC: To charge the brakes on the rear trailer.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerA: Can damage parts of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Is necessary to warm up parts of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve a vehicle's gas mileage.
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no more than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement.
questions.explanation: Cargo inside a trailer must be secured appropriately to prevent it from shifting in transit.

questions.question: Who is responsible for the safe operation of a vehicle?
questions.explanation: The person driving a vehicle is responsible for its safe operation. Be sure to perform routine vehicle inspections before operating a commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, what is the maximum leakage rate that is safe for a double combination vehicle?
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side.
questions.explanation: Backing a commercial motor vehicle is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind you. When backing, make frequent checks of the mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Use a helper whenever possible.

questions.question: The radiator cap:
questions.answerA: Should not be removed when the coolant is hot.
questions.answerB: Can be removed when the coolant is hot.
questions.answerC: Should be cool to the touch under normal driving conditions.
questions.explanation: Never remove the radiator cap or any part of the pressurized cooling system until it has cooled. Opening the cap while the system is too hot could release steam and boiling water that could severely burn you. If the radiator cap is cool to the touch, the system is likely cool enough for you to open the cap.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact to better communicate with them.
questions.answerC: Not move out of their path of travel.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, it is most important to get out of their way, if possible. Do not make eye contact with the driver, as doing so could provoke them. Do not let them provoke you with their actions.

questions.question: If a vehicle begins to hydroplane, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Release the accelerator and push in the clutch.
questions.answerC: Pull in the clutch and brake.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, you can regain control by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: Using the brakes creates heat. If too much heat is produced:
questions.answerB: The brakes may squeak more than usual.
questions.explanation: Brakes are designed to take a lot of heat, but drivers should not rely solely on the brakes to slow their vehicle. Brakes may fade and lose their ability to slow down the vehicle if they become too hot, so drivers should also rely on the engine braking effect.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should be done in the same way every time.
questions.answerB: Should be done differently every time.
questions.answerC: Does not always need to include all items of concern.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip vehicle inspection should be done in the same way every time. Consistency will help a driver learn all of the proper steps and decrease the possibility of the driver forgetting to inspect something.

questions.question: If you are braking on dry pavement while traveling at 55 mph, how much distance will brake lag add to your overall stopping distance?
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to the vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: While driving a vehicle, if an unusual noise or feeling occurs, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle makes it until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check out the situation to determine the proper solutions.
questions.explanation: Use your senses during trips to help you identify mechanical issues. If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything that could indicate trouble, you should stop and check it out.

questions.question: Before driving a power steering-equipped vehicle, you should make sure that:
questions.answerA: The fluid is at a proper level.
questions.answerB: The hoses are connected to the battery.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle that is equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should look for leaks in the hoses.

questions.question: When trying to put out an electrical fire, you should:
questions.explanation: B:C fire extinguishers are designed to work on electrical fires and burning liquids. Don't pour water on an electrical fire.

questions.question: An alcohol evaporator in an air brake system:
questions.answerA: Makes the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevents ice from forming in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Lubricates parts of the braking system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems include an evaporator that introduces alcohol into the system. The alcohol can help prevent ice from forming within the system.

questions.question: A bridge formula:
questions.answerA: Permits less weight per axle for axles that are close together.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern for drivers.
questions.explanation: Maximum axle weights are often set by a bridge formula, which sets a lower maximum weight for axles that are close together.

questions.question: If a vehicle is carrying hazardous cargo, placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Only on the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: On the front, rear, and sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Only on the driver’s side of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the front, the rear, and both sides of a vehicle carrying hazardous cargo. They must be readable from any direction.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place an appropriate amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with how the cargo's weight is distributed.
questions.explanation: When loading cargo, it is important that the weight placed on each axle is neither too little nor too much. Inappropriate loading can interfere with steering, create inadequate wheel traction, or damage the axles.

questions.question: When starting an engine, oil pressure should come up to a normal level:
questions.explanation: Look at your truck's gauges when starting the engine. The oil pressure in an engine should come up to a normal level within seconds of the vehicle's engine being started.

questions.question: If you plan to transport hazardous materials, you will:
questions.answerA: Need to obtain a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerB: Need to drive while using flashing lights.
questions.answerC: Need to wear a gas mask.
questions.explanation: You must have a hazardous materials endorsement to transport any hazardous materials that require the vehicle to be placarded.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, it is important to maintain ____ with your vehicle at all times.
questions.explanation: As you exit your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: Alcohol evaporators are:
questions.answerB: Used to introduce alcohol into air brake systems.
questions.answerC: Only allowed in the northern parts of the state.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems have alcohol evaporators, which introduce alcohol into the braking system to help prevent the formation of ice.

questions.question: What is the Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR)?
questions.answerA: The weight stated by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle
questions.answerB: The maximum weight that can be pulled by a vehicle
questions.answerC: The minimum weight that can be hauled by a vehicle
questions.explanation: A Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle.

questions.question: To avoid a collision with a hazard on the roadway:
questions.answerA: You should always try to stop.
questions.answerB: Swerving may be a safer option than stopping.
questions.explanation: Swerving out of the way of a hazard is sometimes safer than trying to stop before reaching the hazard. You can usually turn away from something more quickly than you can come to a complete stop.

questions.question: What is the number one cause of death and injury in a work zone?
questions.explanation: Speeding is the leading cause of death and injury in work zones. Use extra caution when driving near workers in a work zone.

questions.question: What is a drawback of retarders?
questions.answerA: They may not be permitted everywhere.
questions.answerB: They can help to slow a vehicle.
questions.explanation: A retarder is a device that helps to slow a vehicle, reducing the need for a driver to use the brakes. However, these devices can be noisy and are not permitted everywhere.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, the oil pressure should:
questions.answerA: Gradually build up pressure over the span of a few minutes.
questions.answerB: Come up to normal within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Start high, then decrease as the engine is run.
questions.explanation: Oil pressure should come up to normal within seconds of starting the engine.

questions.question: If feeling drowsy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to reach your destination more quickly.
questions.answerC: Safely leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel drowsy while driving, the best thing to do is to stop and get some sleep. A driver trying to push on and finish a trip while fatigued is a major cause of fatal accidents.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, the heaviest cargo should be placed:
questions.answerA: On top of the lightest parts of the cargo.
questions.answerB: Under the lightest parts of the cargo.
questions.answerC: At the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is important that vehicles are not top-heavy, if at all possible. A top-heavy vehicle is at an increased risk of rollover. Place the heaviest pieces of cargo underneath lighter pieces of cargo.

questions.question: When operating a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.explanation: It is critical to the safe operation of a school bus that mirrors be properly adjusted. Always check each mirror before operating the bus.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pressed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal and the floor
