questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop the vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: Passengers may not stand in front of the:
questions.explanation: On a bus designed to carry standing passengers, no passengers may stand in front of the rear of the driver's seat. Any such bus must have a line on the floor, or some other marking, that indicates where passengers may not stand. This is called a standee line.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Show that the engine oil is within safe operating range.
questions.answerC: Show that the oil is below the refill mark.
questions.explanation: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to indicate where the dipstick is located. You will need to show that the oil level is within a safe operating range and above the refill mark.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a single vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 2 psi in a minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS):
questions.answerA: Reduce a vehicle's normal braking capacity.
questions.answerB: Are in addition to other braking systems and do not reduce a vehicle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Are not effective on larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: If equipped, ABS is in addition to a vehicle's normal braking system and does not increase or decrease the braking power of any other system. ABS only activates when a vehicle's wheels are about to lock.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: With the exception of the straight line backing exercise, a driver may exit their vehicle and check its position during testing exercises up to:
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic vehicle control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: A safety valve is set to open at ____ pounds per square inch (psi).
questions.explanation: The safety valve protects air tanks and the rest of an air brake system from accumulating too much air pressure. The safety valve is usually set to open at 150 psi.

questions.question: When approaching a drawbridge with a green light:
questions.answerC: You must wait for the light to change to yellow.
questions.explanation: A bus does not need to stop before crossing a drawbridge controlled by a green signal light. The driver should still slow down and verify that it is safe before crossing.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerA: Not be used by the driver.
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: When driving with passengers, a bus driver should:
questions.answerA: Engage in conversation with the passengers.
questions.answerB: Not engage in conversation with passengers.
questions.answerC: Ask passengers to watch out the windows for hazards.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming distracted, a bus driver should not engage in conversation with passengers.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: Fueling a bus while passengers are on board is:
questions.answerA: Recommended, but only if the passengers are told about the refueling.
questions.answerB: Recommended, but only if time is an issue.
questions.explanation: A bus should not be refueled while passengers are on board unless it is absolutely necessary. In particular, a bus with passengers on board should never be refueled inside an enclosed building.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: ABS allows a driver to:
questions.answerB: Maintain control of their vehicle while braking.
questions.answerC: See farther ahead of their vehicle.
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to help prevent wheel lockup and help a driver maintain control of their vehicle when braking on a slippery surface.

questions.question: Carry-on baggage:
questions.answerA: May be left in the aisle.
questions.answerB: Must be secured away from exits.
questions.answerC: Should be placed near the doors.
questions.explanation: Bus passengers should not be allowed to leave baggage in any doorway or aisle. Baggage and freight must be secured in a manner that will prevent damage, allow the driver to move freely and easily, allow riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency, and protect riders from injury if the items fall or shift.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you will receive points if you:
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Take the time to ensure that each handhold and railing is securely in place and safe to be used.

questions.question: An inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: Inspect the outside of the bus.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus. It should be adjusted to show every student on the bus, including the students directly behind the driver.

questions.question: At stops, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Warn exiting passengers about potential hazards.
questions.explanation: At bus stops, drivers should warn passengers about potential hazards. This may include warning them to watch their step when exiting the bus by way of lowered stairways.

questions.question: If a bus has stopped at an intermediate stop or its final destination, passengers should be told:
questions.explanation: When stopping a bus at either an intermediate stop or its final destination, the driver should announce the location of the stop, the reason for stopping, the next departure time, and the bus number.

questions.question: During a trip, carry-on baggage:
questions.answerA: May be left in the aisle.
questions.answerB: Must be stored away from the aisle.
questions.answerC: Must be kept on the rider’s lap.
questions.explanation: The aisles and stairwells on a bus must always be kept clear. It is important to keep aisles clear so that no passengers trip while using them.

questions.question: What kind of brakes do most newer heavy-duty trucks use?
questions.explanation: Most newer heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems which use a single set of brake controls.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: When completing a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerA: Not be used by the driver.
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pressed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop the vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: When operating a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.explanation: It is critical to the safe operation of a school bus that mirrors be properly adjusted. Always check each mirror before operating the bus.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerC: Drive straight into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: If an air compressor is belt-driven, the belt should be routinely checked to ensure that it is:
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. Check the tightness of the belt and verify that it is in good condition.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, air pressure should build from 85 to 100 psi within ____ seconds.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: When you are about to start down a hill, you should switch into a ____ gear.
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, be sure to switch into a low gear. Gravity will increase your vehicle's speed as you travel downhill.

questions.question: School buses:
questions.answerB: Are only equipped with ABS if located in cold climates.
questions.explanation: Most commercial vehicles manufactured after 1998 or 1999 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). Many older buses are also equipped with ABS.

questions.question: Which of the following is not part of a vehicle’s air brake system?
questions.explanation: Components of an air brake system include an air compressor, an air compressor governor, air storage tanks, air tank drains, an alcohol evaporator, a safety valve, a brake pedal, foundation brakes, supply pressure gauges, an application pressure gauge, a low air pressure warning signal, a stop light switch, a front brake limiting valve (on some older vehicles), spring brakes, and parking brake controls.

questions.question: After arriving to a destination, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Remind passengers to take their belongings with them when they exit.
questions.answerC: Only make announcements after passengers have begun to exit the bus.
questions.explanation: When arriving at a final destination or intermediate stop, a bus driver should remind passengers to take their belongings with them when exiting the bus. It is best for the driver to make this announcement before the bus comes to a complete stop.

questions.question: With the exception of the straight line backing exercise, a driver may exit their vehicle and check its position during testing exercises up to:
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic vehicle control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: A hazardous material's identification number should appear:
questions.answerC: On a sticker near the material's shipping container.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It also must appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: ____ is responsible for properly labeling hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: When you are behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials classified as poisonous are also flammable.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may not be kept:
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s door.
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door.
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers must be quickly accessible in the event of an emergency. While driving, operators must keep the papers in a pouch on the driver’s door or in clear view and within immediate reach while their seat belt is fastened. Shipping papers may be kept on the driver’s seat when the driver is out of the vehicle.

questions.question: If you are transporting hazardous materials and the cargo is on fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to put it out with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerB: Contact emergency personnel and let them battle the fire.
questions.answerC: Hope the fire goes out by itself.
questions.explanation: Fighting a hazardous materials fire requires special training and protective gear. Unless you have the proper equipment and training, do not try to fight a hazardous materials fire yourself.

questions.question: When loading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use:
questions.explanation: Always protect containers of hazardous materials. When loading hazardous materials, never use equipment that could damage containers or packaging, such as hooks.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may need to be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or properly marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: If accepting a shipment, what could indicate that the cargo contains hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged on wood pallets.
questions.explanation: Cylinders and drums are often used to contain hazardous materials. Be sure to take the proper precautions if transporting a cargo of hazardous materials.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation surrounds the package and will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be transported in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on their side.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.explanation: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a federal security threat assessment done by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the box must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages that contain liquid containers must have orientation markers. Arrows displayed on the box should be pointing in the correct upright direction.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may be:
questions.answerA: Kept in a pouch attached to the driver's side door.
questions.answerB: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials, a driver:
questions.answerA: Should not cross a railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching a railroad crossing, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, you must stop before crossing railroad tracks. This is true whether the tanks are full or empty.

questions.question: The National Response Center must be notified of an incident resulting in any of the following, except:
questions.explanation: The National Response Center must be notified of any incident that results in death; hospitalization; $50,000 or more in estimated property damage; an evacuation of the general public or closure of a major transportation route/facility for more then one hour; fire, breakage, spillage, or suspected contamination involving radiation, bacteria, or toxins. Additionally, if the carrier judges the situation to be so serious that it should be reported, it should be reported.

questions.question: On a shipping paper describing both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may be identified by being:
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper includes information about both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous items must be clearly identified on the paper. They may be entered first, highlighted in a contrasting color, or identified with an "X" placed before the shipping description.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You may proceed across the tracks without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track, regardless of the presence of a train.

questions.question: A shipping paper:
questions.answerA: Is not needed for most shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Is required for all shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be kept in a digital file.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide proper shipping papers to communicate the risks of the materials.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on shipping papers:
questions.answerA: An inhalation hazard placard must be used, but only if more than 100 pounds of the material are being transported.
questions.answerB: An inhalation hazard placard must be used when any amount of the material is being transported.
questions.answerC: Air masks must be provided to anyone handling the cargo.
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" are on a package or its shipping paper, you must display the proper inhalation hazard placards, as well as any other necessary placards. This applies regardless of the amount of materials being carried.

questions.question: If a driver is given a leaking package or shipment, they should:
questions.answerC: Leave it on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to refuse packages or shipments of hazardous materials if they contain leaks.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 materials should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gases), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids), the use of heaters in the same space is generally prohibited.

questions.question: You may leave a vehicle that is carrying explosives unattended:
questions.answerC: On the shoulder of a highway.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, your vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of the road.

questions.question: Unless excepted, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: Unless excepted, hazardous materials shipping papers must list an emergency response telephone number.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, the identification number, shipping name, and hazard class should:
questions.answerA: Be abbreviated if using a small piece of paper.
questions.answerB: Only be abbreviated if the abbreviations are easy to understand.
questions.explanation: On hazardous materials shipping papers, the identification number, shipping name, and hazard class must not be abbreviated, unless specifically authorized in the hazardous materials regulations.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is which shape?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: If cargo containing hazardous materials is leaking but the driver does not have access to a phone, they should:
questions.answerA: Drive to a phone to alert emergency personnel.
questions.answerB: Drive to a designated hazardous materials clean-up facility.
questions.explanation: If a cargo of hazardous materials begins to leak, do not move your vehicle any more than safety requires. If you continue to drive, an even larger area will become contaminated. Instead, you should park your vehicle, secure it, stay with the vehicle, and contact the proper emergency personnel. If you do not have access to a phone, you should send someone else to get help.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are usually shaped like:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are usually diamond-shaped.

questions.question: How do you label a package if the hazardous materials label will not fit onto the package?
questions.answerA: Place the label on a tag securely attached to the item.
questions.answerB: Attach a QR Code to be scanned.
questions.answerC: Reduce the size of the HazMat label to fit it completely on the item.
questions.explanation: Shippers should place applicable diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on hazardous materials packages. If a label will not fit entirely onto a package, shippers may instead place the label on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: Shippers package in order to ____ hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Shippers package hazardous materials in a way that is meant to completely contain the materials. Vehicles should be placarded to communicate the risk of the cargo.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: Keep liquid discharge valves on a compressed gas tank closed except when loading and unloading.

questions.question: If you identify hazardous materials leaking while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving to find a phone booth and call the National Response Center.
questions.answerC: Leave the area to find help.
questions.explanation: If you discover that a cargo of hazardous materials is leaking from your vehicle, you should park the vehicle as soon as possible. The longer you continue driving, the longer the trail of contamination becomes. While this creates potential danger and harm to others, it also increases clean-up expenses.

questions.question: If you're transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you should notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down while you are transporting explosives and you need to use warning signals, use reflective triangles or red electric lights. Never use burning signals, such as flares or fuses, when transporting explosives.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the box must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages that contain liquid containers must have orientation markers. Arrows displayed on the box should be pointing in the correct upright direction.

questions.question: Hazardous materials may be transported:
questions.answerA: By any driver with a CDL.
questions.answerB: By a driver with a CDL and hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: In rural areas by any driver.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to operate a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must carry a fire extinguisher with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials must be listed first.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials must be written larger.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials must be listed in red ink.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper lists both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be entered first.

questions.question: What does a shipping paper describe?
questions.answerB: How the materials will be transported
questions.answerC: Who should accept the materials being transported
questions.explanation: Among other information, shipping papers must include a description of the specific hazardous materials being transported.

questions.question: When loading containers of hazardous materials, you should not use:
questions.explanation: Always protect containers of hazardous materials. When loading hazardous materials, never use equipment that could damage containers or packaging, such as hooks.

questions.question: As a driver, which of the following is not your job at the scene of an accident?
questions.answerA: Keeping people away from the scene.
questions.answerB: Taking heroic measures to put the fire out.
questions.answerC: Communicating the danger of the hazardous materials to response personnel.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in an accident while carrying hazardous materials, it is your responsibility as the driver to keep people away from the scene; limit the spread of material if you can safely do so; inform emergency response personnel of the dangers posed by the materials; and provide emergency personnel with the shipping papers and emergency response information. Unless you have protective equipment and the necessary training, do not try to fight hazardous materials fires yourself.

questions.question: When you are behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: The only way to effectively check your tire pressure is:
questions.answerC: By pushing on the tire to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.explanation: You should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport materials that are categorized as Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases). Do not smoke or carry a lit cigar, pipe, or cigarette near a vehicle containing flammable or explosive materials.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may not be kept:
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s door.
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door.
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers must be quickly accessible in the event of an emergency. While driving, operators must keep the papers in a pouch on the driver’s door or in clear view and within immediate reach while their seat belt is fastened. Shipping papers may be kept on the driver’s seat when the driver is out of the vehicle.

questions.question: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, your vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of the road.

questions.question: You can find the identification numbers assigned to hazardous chemicals:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guide.
questions.explanation: The U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT)'s Emergency Response Guide provides information about hazardous materials, indexed by proper shipping names and hazardous materials identification numbers.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is shaped like a:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are diamond-shaped.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be in the vehicle?
questions.explanation: If transporting chlorine in cargo tanks, a driver must have an approved gas mask in their vehicle.

questions.question: If loading corrosive materials, you should not:
questions.explanation: If loading by hand, load breakable containers of corrosive liquid one by one. Keep them facing upright. Do not drop or roll the containers.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the markings and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: All packages are labeled as poison.
questions.explanation: It is always a good idea to compare package markings and labels to accompanying shipping papers. Always make sure the shipper has displayed the correct basic description on the shipping paper and has provided the proper labels on the packages.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you may park no closer than ____ from the nearest building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you should not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building, unless you are parking for a short period of time while performing an operational necessity, like refueling.

questions.question: If you are transporting hazardous materials and the cargo is on fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to put it out with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerB: Contact emergency personnel and let them battle the fire.
questions.answerC: Hope the fire goes out by itself.
questions.explanation: Fighting a hazardous materials fire requires special training and protective gear. Unless you have the proper equipment and training, do not try to fight a hazardous materials fire yourself.

questions.question: If transporting explosives:
questions.answerA: You must have a written route plan.
questions.answerB: You should take the shortest possible route.
questions.explanation: If transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you must follow a written route plan. Whenever placarded, avoid heavily populated areas, crowds, tunnels, narrow streets, and alleys. Be sure to research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: If you discover that your cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: When Division 1.3 materials are being transported, the floor liner should be:
questions.explanation: You should use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors must be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are any metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to hold a label, it should be labeled:
questions.answerC: By being placed in a certain part of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If a hazardous materials label will not fit onto a package, it may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: A shipping paper:
questions.answerA: Is not needed for most shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Is required for all shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be kept in a digital file.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide proper shipping papers to communicate the risks of the materials.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply the warning placards.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 materials should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gases), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids), the use of heaters in the same space is generally prohibited.

questions.question: An emergency brake must be controlled by:
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. Because air pressure can eventually leak away, emergency and parking brakes should be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: Bridges usually freeze:
questions.answerA: Only once temperatures drop significantly below 32 degrees Fahrenheit.
questions.explanation: Bridges tend to freeze before other parts of the roadway. Be particularly careful on bridges when temperatures are close to the freezing point.

questions.question: When changing lanes, turn signals:
questions.answerB: Should only be used if a vehicle is close to you.
questions.explanation: Always signal your intentions before turning or changing lanes. Do not assume that other drivers will move out of your way simply because you are signaling to turn.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance of driving to:
questions.answerA: Recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.explanation: Once you have begun to drive after a tire has been changed, you should stop after a short distance to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: To help prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Placed as high as possible inside a trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed as low as possible inside a trailer.
questions.answerC: Placed on the driver’s side of a trailer.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is top-heavy, it is more likely to roll over. The weight of cargo should be positioned as low in a trailer as possible to minimize this risk.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by one-half or more when traveling on packed snow.

questions.question: If driving so slowly that you could impede other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using your four-way flashers.
questions.answerC: Wave an arm out the window.
questions.explanation: If you must drive so slowly that you will impede the flow of traffic, you should turn on your four-way flashers to alert drivers behind you (as long as local laws allow the use of flashers).

questions.question: If a vehicle is power steering-equipped, the hoses should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: Explosives are placed in hazardous materials Class 1.

questions.question: What eliminates alcohol from the bloodstream?
questions.explanation: The body processes alcohol at a fixed rate that cannot be sped up through tricks like drinking coffee. The only way to sober up is to give the body the time it needs to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: What should you do if the braking system cannot build up hydraulic pressure?
questions.answerC: Hold the brake pedal down as far as it will go.
questions.explanation: If your hydraulic braking system will not build up the pressure needed to slow or stop your vehicle, there are a few possible solutions. Try shifting into a lower gear, pumping the brakes, and/or using the emergency brake.

questions.question: Aggressive driving is:
questions.answerA: Operating a vehicle in a selfish or pushy manner.
questions.answerB: Operating a vehicle with a strong regard for other motorists’ safety.
questions.answerC: Operating a vehicle in the left lane.
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is the act of operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner and without regard for the rights or safety of other road users.

questions.question: If you’re not sure what to do to extinguish a fire in your vehicle, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire in your vehicle, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: If the emergency air line loses pressure:
questions.answerA: The Anti-Lock Braking System will activate.
questions.answerB: The service air line will activate.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line controls the emergency brakes on a combination vehicle. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: A thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces is called:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: A jogger wearing a stereo headset:
questions.answerA: Is probably aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerB: May not be aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerC: Can hear the sounds of traffic.
questions.explanation: Be careful around pedestrians, joggers, and cyclists who are wearing headphones. They may be unable to hear your vehicle approaching and may do dangerous things because they do not know you are there.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see and you are traveling near other drivers, you should:
questions.explanation: Use your low beam headlights when traveling near other drivers at times when it is difficult to see, such as at dawn, at dusk, or in poor weather conditions. Using the high beam setting under certain conditions could make it difficult for other drivers to see.

questions.question: If a vehicle is accompanied by a vehicle inspection report:
questions.answerA: The driver should first inspect the vehicle, then compare their notes with the report.
questions.answerB: The driver should first look at the report when completing an inspection.
questions.answerC: The driver should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and should rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: As the first step of a vehicle inspection, a driver should review any inspection report left by the previous driver.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Explain what you would inspect and why.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. During this inspection, you must explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why you are inspecting those items.

questions.question: When starting an engine:
questions.answerB: Warning lights should turn on, then quickly turn off.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: If there is a cargo fire in a box trailer:
questions.answerA: The trailer doors should be opened.
questions.answerB: The trailer doors should not be opened.
questions.answerC: A large, heavy blanket should be put over the trailer.
questions.explanation: The doors of a trailer should be not be opened in the event of a cargo fire, especially if the cargo includes hazardous materials. Opening trailer doors would increase the fire's oxygen supply, potentially causing the fire to increase in size.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: It is best not to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive under foggy conditions, be sure to decrease your speed.

questions.question: One way to prevent drowsiness while driving is to:
questions.answerC: Get adequate sleep the night before the trip.
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness. Exercising regularly can increase your energy levels and make you less likely to become tired while driving.

questions.question: When coupling together two trailers, you can secure the second trailer by:
questions.answerC: Placing it at the base of a hill.
questions.explanation: If you are attaching a second trailer to a combination, but you have doubts about the trailer's brakes, you should use wheel chocks to secure the trailer in place while coupling.

questions.question: When using your turn signal, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn the signal off before beginning the turn.
questions.answerC: Signal only if vehicles are in front of you.
questions.explanation: Always begin signaling well in advance of a turn. This is the best way to ensure that other drivers do not try to pass you. Without using a turn signal, drivers may assume that you are merely slowing down or stopping when you are planning to turn.

questions.question: How can you tell if a converter dolly is equipped with anti-lock brakes?
questions.answerA: The dolly is marked with a sticker displaying the letters "ABS."
questions.answerB: There is a plaque on the side of the dolly containing the information.
questions.answerC: There is a yellow lamp on the left side of the dolly.
questions.explanation: Converter dollies built on or after March 1, 1998 are required to have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). The presence of ABS will be indicated by a yellow lamp on the left side of the dolly.

questions.question: The leading factor resulting in death and injury in work zones is:
questions.explanation: The leading cause of injury and death in roadway work zones is excessive speed by passing drivers. Lower your speed when driving through a work zone.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Tread of 3/32 of an inch in the grooves of the front tires
questions.explanation: When checking the tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, make sure the tires have sufficient tread. There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread in every major groove of the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on the other tires. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: Why do large vehicles use air brakes?
questions.answerA: Other brake systems squeak too loudly.
questions.answerB: Air brakes are very effective systems.
questions.answerC: Other braking systems are hard to come by.
questions.explanation: If used and maintained properly, air brakes are a safe and effective way to stop large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: Alcohol evaporators are:
questions.answerB: Used to add alcohol to braking systems to prevent items from freezing.
questions.answerC: Only allowed on vehicles carrying hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems include an alcohol evaporator. The evaporator introduces alcohol into the braking system to prevent the formation of ice, which can cause damage.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that the nuts are loose. If you find rust near the wheel nuts, check their tightness before beginning to drive.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with one or more trailers, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the trailers are straight. Mirror adjustment should be checked before the start of every trip.

questions.question: Before attempting to put out an engine fire:
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The accelerator should be depressed to use up the remaining fuel.
questions.explanation: If you experience an engine fire, you should turn off the engine as soon as safely possible. Avoid opening the vehicle's hood when extinguishing the fire.

questions.question: What is the best way to stop if your brakes fail while you are driving downhill?
questions.answerB: Let the vehicle slow down on its own.
questions.answerC: Let rumble strips slow your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, you will need to quickly find something outside that can stop your vehicle. An escape ramp is the best option. If no escape ramp is available, use the least hazardous available option, such as driving into an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: One way to avoid becoming an aggressive driver is to:
questions.answerA: Talk on your cell phone while driving.
questions.answerC: Set realistic expectations regarding travel time.
questions.explanation: To help avoid frustration, which can lead to aggressive driving behavior, you should begin a trip with realistic expectations about your travel time. Plan ahead to allow time for potential traffic delays. Other strategies to help prevent aggressive driving behavior include driving an appropriate speed and keeping a reasonable following distance; avoiding making gestures at other drivers; and keeping your hands on the steering wheel.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely on warning signals to indicate if a train is approaching.
questions.answerB: Rely on the actions of other motorists to indicate if a train is approaching.
questions.answerC: Not rely solely on warning signals to indicate if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: You should not rely solely upon the presence of warning signals, gates, or flaggers to alert you to the approach of a train. Be especially alert to approaching trains at crossings that are not controlled by gates or signals. At any railroad crossing, you should operate under the assumption that a train is coming.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to use your mirrors?
questions.answerC: You are looking at fuel prices.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be part of your normal driving routine, checking your mirrors is especially important when turning, changing lanes, merging, and performing tight maneuvers.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: Outage:
questions.answerA: Is only a concern in warm weather.
questions.answerB: Is the same for each liquid.
questions.answerC: Should be a factor when determining how much liquid to load into a tank vehicle.
questions.explanation: Because liquids expand when their temperatures increase, some space must be left in a tank to accommodate the expansion. This space is referred to as "outage." The amount of required outage is different for different liquids.

questions.question: When should mirrors be adjusted?
questions.explanation: Mirror adjustment should be checked prior to the start of any trip. If your vehicle has a trailer, the trailer must be straight in order for the mirrors to be checked accurately.

questions.question: Before entering a curve, you should:
questions.explanation: It is important that the driver of a CMV always downshifts before entering a curve.

questions.question: If you are backing and the trailer begins to drift off-course, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Return the steering wheel to the 12 o’clock position.
questions.answerB: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction of the drift.
questions.answerC: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the drift.
questions.explanation: If your trailer begins to drift while you are backing, you should correct the drift immediately by turning the top of the steering wheel in the direction of the drift.

questions.question: How can you check hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should move slowly toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by one-half or more when traveling on packed snow.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: When starting from a stop:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should shift to the right.
questions.answerB: A vehicle should be put into third gear.
questions.answerC: A vehicle should not roll back.
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting anything behind you, make sure that your vehicle does not roll back when you start from a complete stop.

questions.question: Operating a tank vehicle that is transporting liquid cargo:
questions.answerA: Is not permitted during normal business hours.
questions.answerB: Is more difficult than operating a tank vehicle transporting solid cargo.
questions.explanation: Driving a tank vehicle filled with liquid cargo is challenging because tanks have high centers of gravity and because liquid cargo is vulnerable to surge. The movement of liquid cargo in transit can make a vehicle unstable.

questions.question: When driving at highway speeds, you should watch the road about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Stay aware of upcoming obstacles and hazards by consistently watching the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. When traveling at highway speeds, this is equivalent to about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should not be used while you are driving because:
questions.answerA: It will disconnect from the vehicle.
questions.answerB: You will stop the vehicle too quickly.
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while operating your vehicle. Using the trailer hand valve while driving can cause your trailer to skid.

questions.question: To check the automatic transmission fluid level in some vehicles, you will have to:
questions.explanation: In some vehicles, it may be necessary to leave the engine running when checking the automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter a cab due to:
questions.answerB: Using the wrong type of fuel.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: A faulty exhaust system is a serious safety hazard. It may allow poisonous fumes to enter the vehicle's cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: If an air supply control is in its "emergency" position:
questions.answerB: The trailer emergency brakes will be applied.
questions.answerC: The air supply to the trailer will increase.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "emergency" position, the air supply will be stopped and the trailer emergency brakes will be applied.

questions.question: When the vehicle is being operated, vents:
questions.explanation: Before driving a tank, make sure the vents and manhole covers have gaskets and that they close correctly. Vents should be kept clear to ensure that they work correctly.

questions.question: What should you do if the braking system cannot build up hydraulic pressure?
questions.answerC: Hold the brake pedal down as far as it will go.
questions.explanation: If your hydraulic braking system will not build up the pressure needed to slow or stop your vehicle, there are a few possible solutions. Try shifting into a lower gear, pumping the brakes, and/or using the emergency brake.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerB: Should be repaired, but not immediately.
questions.explanation: The suspension system performs the vital functions of holding up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in the suspension are therefore extremely dangerous.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: When starting an engine:
questions.answerB: Warning lights should turn on, then quickly turn off.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: When driving, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Avoid using your mirrors while in heavy traffic.
questions.answerB: Look only to the front and right side of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Look to the front, sides, and rear of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Scan the road ahead and make regular checks of the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while you are driving.

questions.question: To help prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Placed as high as possible inside a trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed as low as possible inside a trailer.
questions.answerC: Placed on the driver’s side of a trailer.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is top-heavy, it is more likely to roll over. The weight of cargo should be positioned as low in a trailer as possible to minimize this risk.

questions.question: On a shipping paper describing both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may be identified by being:
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper includes information about both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous items must be clearly identified on the paper. They may be entered first, highlighted in a contrasting color, or identified with an "X" placed before the shipping description.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle with empty cargo tanks that are used to transport hazardous materials, a driver:
questions.answerA: Should not cross a railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: Needs to slow when approaching a railroad crossing, but is not required to stop.
questions.answerC: Must stop at a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has cargo tanks that are used to carry hazardous materials, you must stop before crossing railroad tracks. This is true whether the tanks are full or empty.

questions.question: During a cargo fire, opening the trailer doors may actually cause the fire to expand because doing so:
questions.answerB: Changes the temperature of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Provides more moisture to the trailer.
questions.explanation: When experiencing a cargo fire, it may be a bad idea to open the doors to the trailer. Doing so allows oxygen to enter the area, potentially causing the fire to flare up and expand.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check all belts for tightness and excessive wear. You should learn how much "give" is appropriate for each belt.

questions.question: If driving in extremely hot weather and the air pressure in your tires is too high, you should:
questions.answerC: Let the tires cool before continuing to drive.
questions.explanation: Air expands as it gets warmer, so the air pressure in your tires could reach dangerously high levels while being driven in very hot weather. If this happens, stop and let your tires cool. Do not let air out of the tires, as this could result in the pressure dropping to an unsafe level once they cool down.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to use your mirrors?
questions.answerC: You are looking at fuel prices.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be part of your normal driving routine, checking your mirrors is especially important when turning, changing lanes, merging, and performing tight maneuvers.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a recommended way to spot potential signs of trouble?
questions.answerC: Checking critical items only at the beginning and end of a trip
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly make checks to ensure that your vehicle is operating properly. Check the instrument panel and gauges; look at your mirrors; and examine the tires, cargo, and lights. Use all of your senses and be alert for anything that could be an early indication of trouble.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and tell them of the driver's behavior.
questions.answerC: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you see a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on shipping papers:
questions.answerA: An inhalation hazard placard must be used, but only if more than 100 pounds of the material are being transported.
questions.answerB: An inhalation hazard placard must be used when any amount of the material is being transported.
questions.answerC: Air masks must be provided to anyone handling the cargo.
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" are on a package or its shipping paper, you must display the proper inhalation hazard placards, as well as any other necessary placards. This applies regardless of the amount of materials being carried.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person who should concern motorists?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to a passenger in their vehicle
questions.answerB: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.answerC: A construction worker on the side of the road
questions.explanation: You should be cautious when you are near people who are not paying attention to the road. Drivers and pedestrians who are talking to someone may be distracted by the conversation and not fully paying attention to the road. Workers on or near the road may not be paying attention to traffic because they are focused on their work, and can themselves also be a distraction to drivers.

questions.question: When are people usually the least alert?
questions.explanation: Most drivers are the least alert at night, especially after midnight. Therefore, crashes due to fatigued driving are more likely at night than any other time of day.

questions.question: The minimum acceptable tread depth for rear tires is:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch on the other tires. Tires on the same vehicle should all be the same size.

questions.question: When you are behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.explanation: Braking after a tire fails can result in a loss of control. Stay off your brakes, if possible, until your vehicle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: When glad hands are coupled, the seals should be pressed together at a ____ angle.
questions.explanation: When coupling, be sure to couple the proper glad hands. When glad hands are connected, the seals should be pressed together at a 90-degree angle.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in a trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.answerC: Left to air dry without washing.
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to corrosive liquids must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: When checking windshield wiper blades, they should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check the wiper blades for damage, stiff rubber, and proper securement. Clean the blades if they are dirty.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerA: Only occurs at extremely high speeds.
questions.answerB: Can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.
questions.answerC: Happens most frequently when tire pressure is too high.
questions.explanation: If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph. It is most likely if the tires' air pressure is too low or if tires' tread is worn.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely pass under an upcoming bridge, you should:
questions.explanation: If you aren't sure that you have room for your vehicle to safely fit under an overhead object, you should slow down while approaching it. Seek an alternate route, if possible.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: The center of gravity in a trailer should be:
questions.answerC: At the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: The weight of cargo in a vehicle should be distributed as low as possible. Having a center of gravity that is too high will increase the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time in order to place emphasis on different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time to prevent you from forgetting anything.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: On flat surfaces, wheel chocks:
questions.answerA: Can be used to prevent a parked vehicle from moving.
questions.answerB: Make it easier for a parked vehicle to roll.
questions.answerC: Should only be used on the front driver's side tire.
questions.explanation: In situations where a driver cannot use a parking brake, wheel chocks can be used to hold a parked vehicle in place on a level surface.

questions.question: A posted speed limit for cars:
questions.answerB: May be too fast for buses.
questions.answerC: May be too slow for buses.
questions.explanation: Particularly on curves, the maximum posted speed limit may be safe to be driven in a car but too fast to be driven in a bus. Be especially careful when the road has been made slippery by rain or snow.

questions.question: How much distance will an air brake-equipped vehicle need to come to a complete stop if it is traveling at 55 mph under ideal driving conditions?
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: What kind of brakes do most newer heavy-duty trucks use?
questions.explanation: Most newer heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems which use a single set of brake controls.

questions.question: The ____ between an air compressor and reservoir tank prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: What is often found in compressed air?
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Fueling a bus while passengers are on board is:
questions.answerB: Acceptable only on trips of more than 100 miles.
questions.answerC: Acceptable only if doing so is unavoidable.
questions.explanation: A bus should not be refueled while passengers are on board unless it is absolutely necessary to do so. In particular, a bus with riders on board should never be refueled inside an enclosed building.

questions.question: When transporting a load, the cargo should be inspected:
questions.answerB: Only after a trip is finished.
questions.answerC: Every time you take a break.
questions.explanation: Cargo and its securement must be inspected every time you take a break during a trip. Be sure to inspect the cargo at least every 150 miles.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, what is the maximum leakage rate that is safe for a double combination vehicle?
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, if one air system is very low on pressure:
questions.answerA: None of the brakes will work at all.
questions.answerB: Either the front or rear brakes will not be fully operable.
questions.answerC: There is usually no noticeable effect.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, either the front or rear brakes will not be fully operable if one of the air systems gets too low on pressure. If the air pressure in either tank gets too low while you are driving, you should exit the road and park as soon as possible.

questions.question: Blocking a load:
questions.answerA: Is only done with liquid cargo.
questions.answerC: Is dangerous and should never be done.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit.

questions.question: After arriving to a destination, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Remind passengers to take their belongings with them when they exit.
questions.answerC: Only make announcements after passengers have begun to exit the bus.
questions.explanation: When arriving at a final destination or intermediate stop, a bus driver should remind passengers to take their belongings with them when exiting the bus. It is best for the driver to make this announcement before the bus comes to a complete stop.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Look both ways, but do not need to stop.
questions.answerB: Stop and get out of the bus to look for a train.
questions.answerC: Stop before the railroad tracks and look both ways before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing while driving a bus, you must stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track to look and listen for any approaching trains. Only proceed once you are certain that there are no approaching trains. You do not need to stop at streetcar crossings; if a police officer or flagger is directing traffic; if there is a green traffic signal at the crossing; or at crossings marked "exempt" or "abandoned."

questions.question: A driver can rely on front wheel braking to work:
questions.answerC: Under all conditions, except for snow.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: What should happen before the air pressure in an air brake system tank falls below 55 psi?
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be unable to shift out of gear.
questions.explanation: The low air pressure warning signal must activate before the air supply pressure drops below 55 psi in the air tank. If the warning signal does not turn on when being tested during an inspection, the vehicle is not safe to drive.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located inside:
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, you should:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place a well-balanced amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with how the weight is distributed.
questions.explanation: A load of cargo must be properly balanced. Placing too much weight over an axle can damage the axle and make it more difficult for you to steer. Placing too little weight over an axle can cause poor traction, also leading to difficult handling.

questions.question: Hanging meat as cargo is usually:
questions.explanation: A cargo of hanging meat can be very unstable, both because the meat swings about in transit and because its center of gravity is high.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to cover cargo?
questions.answerA: To protect people from spilled cargo
questions.answerB: To protect the cargo from weather
questions.answerC: To protect the cargo from animals
